title: Simple Guide on to How to Grow Capsicums (Hoho) | Capsicums Farming in Kenya

tasks.task: Preparing and planting Capscum seeds in Kenya
subtasks: Researching and selecting the best Capscum variety (Maxibel or Superbale F1)
Soaking Capscum seeds in a solution (optimizer or seed shooter) to accelerate germination
Covering seeds with a germination enhancer (black pepper) to shorten germination period
Ensuring suitable soil conditions (deep, fertile, well-draining)
Avoiding soil previously used for potatoes or tomatoes to prevent pests and diseases
Planting at optimal times (February and September) for high market demand
Maintaining proper spacing (45 cm by 45 cm, around 20,000 plants per acre)
Preparing beds with weld compost and farmyard manure before transplanting
Transplanting and applying insecticides (thunder) and foliar feeds (city shooter) post-transplant
Fertilizer application schedule (DAP, NPK-317, CAN) at specific intervals (14, 14, and 60 days after transplanting)
Managing pests (Lead Spider Mides, hot flies, cutworms, nematodes) with appropriate insecticides (profile, escort, zander, pentagon, alonze, marshall)
Controlling diseases (Botrytis, downy mildew, Fusarium wilt, bacterial wilt) using fungicides (Ridomil gold, mistrust, absolute) and bactericides (GreenComp)
Soaking seeds in a seed optimizer solution
Covering seeds with black pepper to enhance germination
Ensuring adequate soaking time for seed establishment (4 to 5 weeks)
Applying DAP fertilizer 14 days after transplanting
Applying NPK-317 fertilizer 14 days after transplanting
Applying CAN fertilizer 60 days after transplanting
Using foliar fertilizers (Easy Group Vegetative, Advanced K, Curl Max) as needed
Controlling Lead Spider Mites with profile or escort insecticides
Addressing hot flies with zander or accepted insecticides
Protecting seedlings from cutworms using drenches (profile or pentagon)
Treating nematodes with alonze or marshall drenches
Using Ridomil gold or mistrust to control Botrytis
Applying Ridomil gold to manage Downy mildew
Treating Fusarium wilt with absolute fungicide
Employing GreenComp (copper-based) to combat bacterial wilt
Planting during February and September for Easter and Christmas peak markets
Ensuring continuous supply through staggered planting
Selling to brokers for bulk and fast revenues
Harvesting when market prices are highest (around 80 shillings per kilo during peak seasons)
